86.heading: Smith, Ronald L., 1959-
86.title: Black Panther : the Young Prince
86.author: Ronald L
notes: "He felt the mesh of the Vibranium under his fingertips, smooth yet hard at the same time. It almost seemed like it pulsed. Like it wanted to be worn. 'This is the suit of the Black Panther,' T'Challa whispered. 'The suit of my father and his father before him.' He let the fabric fall from his hands and unfurl toward the floor. 'I have to do this,' he said. 'I have no choice.'"
Jacket art and lettering by Josh Talbot.
Superhero fiction.

notes: Begins: "The gloomy, green stretches of jungle were ever a source of surprise to Wambi, who roamed its treacherous trails and shared the life of the wild beasts."
Data from Lou Mougin, Henry Steele, Hames Ware, et al. via Grand Comics Database.

94.heading: Smith, Roy L.
94.title: "Terror of the Jungle!"
94.author: by Roy L
94.appears_in: Smith. 10 p. in Wambi the Jungle Boy, no. 8 (1964).
notes: Title from cover.

Begins: "The most harmless prank can turn out to be dangerous! Long ago, Wambi, the jungle boy, had learned this lesson. Often he preached its wisdom to his animal friends. But now only one thought filled his mind. His little friend Tiku, the monkey, is sick."

95.heading: Smith, Roy L.

101.heading: Smith, Ryan Cecil.
101.title: S.F. #3
101.author: Ryan Cecil Smith.
notes: "S.F. is about a little boy name Hupa Dupa whose family gets blown up by pirates, so he's recruited into the Space Fleet Scientific Foundation Special Forces to fight them. The S.F.S.F.S.F. are racing across the stars to form an alliance of good planets against evil ones and win the galatic war against the terrorist Pirate Nation. Though he's been armed with the ultra-rare Samurai Zero gun & he's being trained by the most elite scientist-fighters in S.F., Hupa Dupa is still just a little kid. He will "try his best" to "take positive action" in order to help somehow!"

109.heading: Smith, Sally.
109.title: "The Greed Virus!"
109.author: [No author]
109.series: Sue and Sally Smith) 10 p. in Sue and Sally Smith, Flying Nurses, no. 54
notes: Begins: "The authorities at Morse Medical Center in the United States dispatched teams to the village in the foothills of the towering Andes Mountains in South America! The specific disease endangering the people there was typhoid, but they suffered from an ancient illness that ate at the soul as well as the body! They were poor, hungry, illiterate, and unloved. Outcasts, they considered themselves, and when Sue and Sally Smith appeared they submitted dumbly to their ministrations! As Paolo De Portega pointed out, they were more like cattle than human beings!"

110.heading: Smith, Sally.
110.title: Sue and Sally Smith, Flying Nurses.
110.author: [No author]
notes: Published no. 48 (Nov. 1962) - no. 54 (Nov. 1963), cf. Overstreet Comic Book Price Guide.
Continues: My Secret Life.
Comic books, strips, etc. I. Charlton Comics Group. II. Flying Nurses. k. Smith. Call no.: PN6728.2.C47Y6

111.heading: Smith, Sally.
111.title: "A Thread of Life"
111.author: [No author]
111.series: Sue and Sally Smith) 10 p. in Sue and Sally Smith, Flying Nurses, no. 52
notes: Begins: "The man held the fate of his people in his hands, but his hands were without strength and death beckoned from the depths 3,000 feet down as the emergency corps helicopter tried to land nurse Sally Smith on the ledge where Jawhal Kul was gasping away his life! She knew the danger, and knew the consequences for Jawhal Kul's countrymen if she failed to save him!"
Summary: Jawhal is a leader in a "backward nation" where there are communists "fomenting violence." In the course of the story Sally Smith gets to punch a "commie" in the chin.

112.heading: Smith, Salty.
112.title: "Against the Chinese"
112.author: Dick Ayers, pencils
notes: Begins: "Chief Petty Officer Battleship Burke and his mate"

Summary: Burke and Salty Smith are on a boring shore leave when they hear a call to help reinforce the front line against the Chinese. They join soldiers from England, Ethiopia and Turkey in battle, with Burke even building a raft to help rout the Chinese from their flank.
Data from Lou Mougin, Ramon Schenk and Michael Hoskin via Grand Comics Database.

113.heading: Smith, Salty.
113.title: "Asbestos Fire-Fighting Suits"
113.author: Dick Ayers, pencils
notes: Begins: "These asbestos fire-fighting suits will keep the flames from us"

Summary: Burke and Salty Smith fend off fires caused by MIGs, then shoot their fire extinguisher foam at the MIGs, making them crash. After escorting a commander to a UN base, they encounter a speedboat full of Chinese agents who try to board and capture their destroyer, but once again use the foam to blind their enemies and take them prisoner.
Data from Lou Mougin, Ramon Schenk and Michael Hoskin via Grand Comics Database.

114.heading: Smith, Sam.
114.title: "Shooting Sam Smith" 2 p. text in Masked Raider
114.author: [No author]

115.heading: Smith, Sandra, 1949-
115.title: The Stranger : Based on the Novel by Albert Camus
115.author: Jacques Ferrandez ; translated by Sandra Smith.
notes: Translation of: L'Étranger.

Summary (from OCLC): The day his mother dies, Meursault notices that it is very hot on the bus that is taking him from Algiers to the retirement home where his mother lived; so hot that he falls asleep. Later, while waiting for the wake to begin, the harsh electric lights in the room make him extremely uncomfortable, so he gratefully accepts the coffee the caretaker offers him and smokes a cigarette. The same burning sun that so oppresses him during the funeral walk will once again blind the calm, reserved Meursault as he walks along a deserted beach a few days later, leading him to commit an irreparable act.

116.heading: Smith, Scott Thompson.
116.title: Graphic Medicine Manifesto
116.author: MK Czerwiec, Ian Williams, Susan Merrill Squier, Michael J
116.appears_in: Green, Kimberly R. Myers, and Scott T. Smith.
notes: Includes bibliographical references.

Summary (from publisher via OCLC): "Combining scholarly essays with visual narratives and a conclusion in comics form, establishes graphic medicine as a new area of scholarship. Demonstrates that graphic medicine narratives offer patients, family members, and medical caregivers new ways to negotiate the challenges of the medical experience. Discusses comics as visual rhetoric."

119.author: G
119.appears_in: Colan. 5 p. in Man Comics, no. 9 (Aug. 1951).
notes: Begins: "There was one thing the army taught me, and only one thing. It rankled deep inside me like a knot of galling poison and made me forget everything else I had learned as a combat infantryman. That one thing was hate. Blind, unreasoning, devastating hate, and it was all directed at one guy, Sergeant Smith"

Narrated by Kevin Spacey.

Executive producers, Bryan Singer and Kevin Burns ; producers, Stacey M. Zipfel, Mark McLaughlin, Scott Hartford ; edited by Kevin Benson, Troy Bogert, David Comtois, John Richardson, Molly Shock ; written by James Grant Goldin and Steven Smith.

Summary: Disc 1. Discusses the history of Superman: how and why he was created, his metamorphosis, and how the concept spread beyond comic books into radio, television, movies, and popular culture ; disc. 2. Filmmaker Bryan Singer's video journal about making the move Superman returns.

198.heading: Smith, Steven.
198.title: "Monster Menace" 1 p. in Monster Menace, no. 3
198.author: [No author]
notes: Letters to the editor from Joey Marchese, Michael T. Gilbert, Steven Smith, Sean Hartter, and Pierce Askegren, and a drawing by Steve Ditko.

199.heading: Smith, Storm.
199.title: "When Storm Smith Strikes!"
199.author: [No author]
199.series: Two-Gun Kid) 5 p. in Mighty Marvel Western, no. 32

200.heading: Smith, Stuart.
200.title: A Dazzling Day
200.author: adapted by Devin Ann Wooster ; illustrated by Brittney Lee ; designed by Stuart Smith.
notes: 1 v. : col. ill. ; 21 cm.
Other title: Disney Tangled : a Dazzling Day.

Summary (from OCLC): The long-haired Princess Rapunzel has spent her entire life in a tower, but when she falls in love with a bandit who was passing by she must venture into the outside world for the first time to find him.
Fantasy fiction.

201.heading: Smith, Sue.
201.title: "Disaster Flight"
201.author: [No author]
201.series: Sue and Sally Smith) 10 p. in Sue and Sally Smith, Flying Nurses, no. 52
notes: Begins: "The captain and the copilot had both been knocked out in the freak accident which had shattered the cockpit windows. And now only the frail strength and limited knowledge of nurse Sue Smith stood between seventy-four persons and certain death!"

202.heading: Smith, Sue.
202.title: "The Greed Virus!"
202.author: [No author]
202.series: Sue and Sally Smith) 10 p. in Sue and Sally Smith, Flying Nurses, no. 54
notes: Begins: "The authorities at Morse Medical Center in the United States dispatched teams to the village in the foothills of the towering Andes Mountains in South America! The specific disease endangering the people there was typhoid, but they suffered from an ancient illness that ate at the soul as well as the body! They were poor, hungry, illiterate, and unloved. Outcasts, they considered themselves, and when Sue and Sally Smith appeared they submitted dumbly to their ministrations! As Paolo De Portega pointed out, they were more like cattle than human beings!"

203.heading: Smith, Sue.
203.title: Sue and Sally Smith, Flying Nurses.
203.author: [No author]
notes: Published no. 48 (Nov. 1962) - no. 54 (Nov. 1963), cf. Overstreet Comic Book Price Guide.
Continues: My Secret Life.
Comic books, strips, etc. I. Charlton Comics Group. II. Flying Nurses. k. Smith. Call no.: PN6728.2.C47Y6

204.heading: Smith, Sue.
204.title: "Symptom of Evil"
204.author: [No author]
204.series: Sue and Sally Smith) 10 p. in Sue and Sally Smith, Flying Nurses, no. 54
notes: Begins: "There were five people in the twin-engined charter plane when it crashed near the Great Slave Lake in northern Canada! It was late August and winter was not far off. A rescue had to be affected before snow fell! Dr. Angus Baird and nurse Sue Smith were dispatched from Morse Memorial Hospital in the United States to the scene of the crash! It had been spotted by another emergency corps' ambulance planes earlier that day."

205.heading: Smith, Susan.
205.title: "It's Beautiful"
205.author: Tom Batiuk.
notes: Summary: Susan gives Les feedback on his writing.

206.heading: Smith, Susan.
206.title: "Lisa's Story"
206.author: Tom Batiuk.
notes: Summary: Susan puts Les's CD in her computer and the title comes up.

207.heading: Smith, Susan.
207.title: "A Toss-up Between Lying on the Beach in Cancun for a Week or Doing some Painting in My House"
207.author: Tom Batiuk.
notes: Summary: Susan Smith tells Les her Spring break plans.

208.heading: Smith, Susan.
208.title: "Two Tickets to the Magic Flutophone"
208.author: Tom Batiuk.
notes: Summary: Cayla invites Les, he accepts, and we see Susan Smith in the foreground also with two tickets.

209.heading: Smith, Susan.
209.title: "Would You Mind Taking a Look At It?"
209.author: Tom Batikuk.
notes: Summary: Les asks Susan as another writer to look at what he's been writing.

210.heading: Smith, Susie Q.
210.title: Susie Q. Smith.
210.author: [No author]
notes: Published no. 323 (Mar. 1951) to no. 553 (Apr. 1954)
Numbering is in the Four-color series and proceeds as follows: 323, 377, 453, 553.
Art signed (no. 453): Linda Walter.

211.heading: Smith, Suzette.
211.title: It's Not That Bad
211.author: Suzette Smith.
notes: Comic zine with stories of Suzette's life, friends and dating in Detroit.

212.heading: Smith, Suzette.
212.title: Votes for Women
212.author: written by Sarah Mirk ; illustrated by Suzette Smith.
notes: (Oregon History Comics ; v. 9)
Includes bibliographical references.
Summary (from OCLC): Cartoon history of the struggle for "woman suffrage" in Oregon, highlighting the efforts of activists Esther Clayson Pohl Lovejoy and Abigail Scott Duniway.

213.heading: Smith, Suzie.
213.title: Batman : The Encyclopedia of Comic Book Heroes, v. 1
213.author: Michael Fleisher

214.title: Smith, Robin
notes: British comics artist. See also his The Bogie Man
